utterances: Anderson says he didn't have to time to grab his wallet.
He became homeless and penniless in a manner of minutes.
He didn't have time to save the animals either.
He said goodbye to a cat named Lucky, three goldfish, and a shepherd dog with one blue eye.
He left the front door wide open.
The family dove into the squad car.
Eight-year-old Violet had an asthma attack.
The Poway Search Department put us in their car and she was - she was just going (makes wheezing sounds).
She puked all over his car and he just - I don't care.
I just want to get you guys to safety.
I met the Andersons at Qualcomm Stadium, the main shelter for thousands of evacuees.
Ryan was asking strangers to borrow a cell phone.
Little Nicole(ph) was getting worried.
I have a couple of friends and they live somewhere where the fire is going to be, and I hope...
(Unintelligible)
Yeah.
Have you talk to them?
No.
No. But my friends live there; they told me that.
And I hope they'll be okay.
Fire is not new to the Andersons.
The Cedar fire of four years ago destroyed the family home in Poway.
So this is not the first time.
This is the second time.
And even after you lost that house, you stayed in the area.
Yes, sir.
You didn't leave.
That's Robert Fovell, professor of Atmospheric and Oceanic Sciences at UCLA, giving a scientific explanation for the very literary Santa Ana winds.
No, sir.
I couldn't afford to.
I'm a single parent who lives on $900 month.
That's all I get.
My rent is $850 a month.
San Diego County I think is one of the greatest places in the world to live.
The reason why is because of how compassionate people are towards other people's needs.
I mean, this is just amazing.
It gives me goose bumps.
After we talked awhile, Ryan started to fall apart.
He pleaded for help to get a hotel room; he didn't want his daughter breathing in the ash all night.
So we put Ryan on the radio.
San Diego member station KPBS has been broadcasting nonstop since the fires began.
Ryan told his story to listeners, and within minutes two people called offering to put the Andersons up for the night.
Just as that news came in, Ryan got an update on his home.
It's gone.
I lost everything.
It's gone.
I lost everything.
Everything is gone.
And my animals are probably dead.
The Andersons' entire apartment complex burned to the ground.
For NPR News, I'm Andrew Phelps in San Diego.
And also at Qualcomm stadium, Rick Craff(ph).
He was at home in Rancho Bernardo, north of San Diego at 5:00 a.m. yesterday.
We received a call from a friend that told us that the fire was burning their house.
We had kind of thought we might get a reverse 911 call or somebody might come pounding on the door, but it was a phone call of a good friend that woke us.
And when you went outside the home, what did you see?
I went to the front door and I saw smoke and ash and embers blowing across the yard.
So we walked out to the front of our garage and looked down the street and saw a house on fire.
Right down the street from your house?
Yes.
How far away?
I would say maybe a hundred yards or less.
So what did you do?
My wife had gone to the airport to pick up some friends that were flying in to town last night and take them home, and we spoke on the phone about midnight and said, you know what?
It looks like it might come this way.
We didn't really think it was going to come this way this fast, but she said, what should we take?
So we determined that we would take our computer, about two boxes of pictures, and we had some financial records.
So we set those things aside before we went to sleep at 1:00 o'clock and we just tossed those things and took off.
Do you know if your home is there?

Half way through the day yesterday on the TV we saw a street, Baladara(ph) Street, which is incredibly close to our house, with a very long line of homes that were burnt to the ground and just chimneys standing.
And then shortly after that, though, my son-in-law was able to get into the area and there are - is a home or homes in our cul-de-sac that were burnt down but our house is still standing.
So we're a little curious to see exactly what that means.
But we know that as of late yesterday afternoon the house was still standing at least.
I wonder how you think about going back there.
I mean, there was a huge fire four years ago in this area, and now this one, which I think is even worse.
Is this a safe place to live anymore?
You know what?

When we lived in South Carolina for a number of years, you know that there could be a hurricane the next season, even if you haven't had one in 50 or 100 years, so I think it's part of living; it's a risk.
No matter where you are, there are risks.
This is definitely a risk, this area.
It will be interesting to see what's left.
I did think last night that we're probably a little bit in a state of denial or maybe a little bit in a state of shock, but I know when we drive up into that neighborhood, we'll see those homes gone.
And I heard that - there's a little strip mall by us as well, and I've heard it partially burned down.
To see that is going to be disheartening and it's going to cause you to kind of reevaluate where you are, and if that's where you need to be.
But right now I'm not ready to pack it in.
Ladies and gentlemen, can we have your attention, please?
Rick Craff from Rancho Bernardo in northeast San Diego County.
Right now he's at Qualcomm Stadium in San Diego.
Rick, thank you and good luck.
Thank you very much, Alex.
Bye-bye.
You've heard us mention the Santa Ana winds as the force behind these fires.
They whip through the literature of Southern California - Joan Didion, Michael Connelly.
And the great L.A.
crime writer Raymond Chandler had it this way...
Those hot, dry winds that come down through the mountain passes and curl your hair and make your nerves jump and your skin itch.
On nights like that, every booze party ends in a fight.
Meek little wives feel the edge of the carving knife and study their husbands' necks.
Anything can happen.
Madeleine, you are a native Californian.
I am from back East.
I heard about these Santa Ana winds but I never really got it.
Watch your neck, Alex.
Robert Fovell, a professor of atmospheric and oceanic sciences at UCLA, says Raymond Chandler got it right, but many people get a few things confused.
Santa Ana winds can be characterized as hot, dry winds that blow out of the desert.
But what many people don't understand, even people who live here, is they don't blow out of the desert because the desert is hot.
They blow out of the desert when the desert is cold.
So that September to March, high pressure builds into the Great Basin of Nevada and Utah, and this cold air swoops up into the mountains and then down into southern California.
But what makes the winds so hot?
They become hot because the Great Basin is at much higher elevation than we are.
If you take air and you bring it down, you're forcing it to compress; and when you compress air, it heats up.
It actually heats up at a very rapid rate, almost 30 degrees Fahrenheit per mile.
The one European team that seems to have performed as advertised: Germany.
Yes.
He had been the chairman of the board of the very institution that was trying to sterilize her.
And he wrote briefs that were not very helpful to her case.
And he seemed, you know, quite pleased with her being sterilized in the end.
